RN   [7]
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=16815440; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2006.06.011;
RA   Joergensen J.P., Lauridsen A.-M., Kristensen P., Dissing K.,
RA   Johnsen A.H., Hendil K.B., Hartmann-Petersen R.;
RT   "Adrm1, a putative cell adhesion regulating protein, is a novel
RT   proteasome-associated factor.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 360:1043-1052(2006).
RN   [8]
RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 22-130, X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.7 ANGSTROMS) OF
RP   1-150, FUNCTION, REGION, AND INTERACTION WITH UBIQUITIN; UCHL5 AND
RP   PSMD1.
RX   PubMed=18497827; DOI=10.1038/nature06924;
RA   Schreiner P., Chen X., Husnjak K., Randles L., Zhang N., Elsasser S.,
RA   Finley D., Dikic I., Walters K.J., Groll M.;
RT   "Ubiquitin docking at the proteasome through a novel pleckstrin-
RT   homology domain interaction.";
RL   Nature 453:548-552(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the 26S proteasome, a multiprotein complex
CC       involved in the ATP-dependent degradation of ubiquitinated
CC       proteins. This complex plays a key role in the maintenance of
CC       protein homeostasis by removing misfolded or damaged proteins,
CC       which could impair cellular functions, and by removing proteins
CC       whose functions are no longer required. Therefore, the proteasome
CC       participates in numerous cellular processes, including cell cycle
CC       progression, apoptosis, or DNA damage repair. Within the complex,
CC       functions as a proteasomal ubiquitin receptor. Engages and thus
CC       activates 19S-associated deubiquitinases UCHL5 and PSMD14 during
CC       protein degradation. UCHL5 reversibly associate with the 19S
CC       regulatory particle whereas PSMD14 is an intrinsic subunit of the
CC       proteasome lid subcomplex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15819879,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18497827}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the 19S proteasome regulatory particle
CC       complex. The 26S proteasome consists of a 20S core particle (CP)
CC       and two 19S regulatory subunits (RP). Interacts with the
CC       proteasomal scaffolding protein PSMD1 (PubMed:18497827). Interacts
CC       with deubiquitinase UCHL5; this interaction activates the auto-
CC       inhibited UCHL5 by deoligomerizing it. Interacts with UBQLN2 and
CC       ubiquitin. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q16186,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18497827}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q99460-1:PSMD1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8762776, EBI-15703973;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15819879}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q16186}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Present in all tissues examined (at protein
CC       level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16815440,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17139257}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The Pru (pleckstrin-like receptor for ubiquitin) domain
CC       mediates interactions with PSMD1 and ubiquitin. Preferential
CC       binding to the proximal subunit of K48-linked diubiquitin allows
CC       UCHL5 access to the distal subunit. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18497827}.
CC   -!- PTM: Not N-glycosylated.
CC   -!- PTM: Not O-glycosylated. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ADRM1 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Although initially described as a cell membrane
CC       glycoprotein, ADRM1 is intracellular and non-glycosylated, and has
CC       probably no direct role in cell adhesion. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.50 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=27428775; DOI=10.1038/nsmb.3273;
RA   Huang X., Luan B., Wu J., Shi Y.;
RT   "An atomic structure of the human 26S proteasome.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 23:778-785(2016).
RN   [17]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (4.50 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=27342858; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1608050113;
RA   Schweitzer A., Aufderheide A., Rudack T., Beck F., Pfeifer G.,
RA   Plitzko J.M., Sakata E., Schulten K., Foerster F., Baumeister W.;
RT   "Structure of the human 26S proteasome at a resolution of 3.9 Aa.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 113:7816-7821(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the 26S proteasome, a multiprotein complex
CC       involved in the ATP-dependent degradation of ubiquitinated
CC       proteins. This complex plays a key role in the maintenance of
CC       protein homeostasis by removing misfolded or damaged proteins,
CC       which could impair cellular functions, and by removing proteins
CC       whose functions are no longer required. Therefore, the proteasome
CC       participates in numerous cellular processes, including cell cycle
CC       progression, apoptosis, or DNA damage repair. The PSMD14 subunit
CC       is a metalloprotease that specifically cleaves 'Lys-63'-linked
CC       polyubiquitin chains within the complex. Plays a role in response
CC       to double-strand breaks (DSBs): acts as a regulator of non-
CC       homologous end joining (NHEJ) by cleaving 'Lys-63'-linked
CC       polyubiquitin, thereby promoting retention of JMJD2A/KDM4A on
CC       chromatin and restricting TP53BP1 accumulation. Also involved in
CC       homologous recombination repair by promoting RAD51 loading.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1317798, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22909820,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9374539}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the 19S proteasome regulatory particle
CC       complex. The 26S proteasome consists of a 20S core particle (CP)
CC       and two 19S regulatory subunits (RP). The regulatory particle is
CC       made of a lid composed of 9 subunits including PSMD4, a base
CC       containing 6 ATPases and few additional components
CC       (PubMed:27428775, PubMed:27342858). Within the complex, PSMD4
CC       interacts with subunit PSMD7 through their respective MPN domain.
CC       Interacts with TXNL1 (PubMed:19349277).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19214193, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19349277,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27342858, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27428775}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9C005:DPY30; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-722193, EBI-744973;
CC       Q8IZU0:FAM9B; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-722193, EBI-10175124;
CC       P50222:MEOX2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-722193, EBI-748397;
CC       P51665:PSMD7; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-722193, EBI-357659;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely expressed. Highest levels in heart and
CC       skeletal muscle. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9374539}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase M67A family. PSMD14
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RN   [22]
RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 1-150, AND INTERACTION WITH UBIQUITIN AND UBQLN2.
RX   PubMed=27396824; DOI=10.1016/j.str.2016.05.018;
RA   Chen X., Randles L., Shi K., Tarasov S.G., Aihara H., Walters K.J.;
RT   "Structures of Rpn1 T1:Rad23 and hRpn13:hPLIC2 reveal distinct binding
RT   mechanisms between substrate receptors and shuttle factors of the
RT   proteasome.";
RL   Structure 24:1257-1270(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the 26S proteasome, a multiprotein complex
CC       involved in the ATP-dependent degradation of ubiquitinated
CC       proteins. This complex plays a key role in the maintenance of
CC       protein homeostasis by removing misfolded or damaged proteins,
CC       which could impair cellular functions, and by removing proteins
CC       whose functions are no longer required. Therefore, the proteasome
CC       participates in numerous cellular processes, including cell cycle
CC       progression, apoptosis, or DNA damage repair. Within the complex,
CC       functions as a proteasomal ubiquitin receptor. Engages and
CC       activates 19S-associated deubiquitinases UCHL5 and PSMD14 during
CC       protein degradation. UCHL5 reversibly associate with the 19S
CC       regulatory particle whereas PSMD14 is an intrinsic subunit of the
CC       proteasome lid subcomplex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16815440,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16906146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16990800,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17139257, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18497817,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24752541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25702870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25702872}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the 19S proteasome regulatory particle
CC       complex. The 26S proteasome consists of a 20S core particle (CP)
CC       and two 19S regulatory subunits (RP) (PubMed:16990800). Interacts
CC       with the proteasomal scaffolding protein PSMD1
CC       (PubMed:16990800,PubMed:16815440, PubMed:16906146,
CC       PubMed:20471946). Interacts with deubiquitinase UCHL5; this
CC       interaction activates the auto-inhibited UCHL5 by deoligomerizing
CC       it (PubMed:17139257, PubMed:24752541, PubMed:25702870,
CC       PubMed:25702872). Interacts with UBQLN2 and ubiquitin
CC       (PubMed:27396824). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16815440,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16906146, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16990800,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17139257, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18497817,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20471946, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24752541,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25702872, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27396824}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P48510:DSK2 (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-6174;
CC       O35593:Psmd14 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-772796;
CC       P55036:PSMD4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-359318;
CC       P54727:RAD23B; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-954531;
CC       P0CG48:UBC; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-3390054;
CC       Q9UMX0:UBQLN1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-741480;
CC       Q9UHD9:UBQLN2; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-947187;
CC       Q9Y5K5:UCHL5; NbExp=20; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-1051183;
CC       Q9Y5K5-3:UCHL5; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-954387, EBI-11749875;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16990800}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16990800}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The Pru (pleckstrin-like receptor for ubiquitin) domain
CC       mediates interactions with PSMD1 and ubiquitin. Preferential
CC       binding to the proximal subunit of K48-linked diubiquitin allows
CC       UCHL5 access to the distal subunit. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18497817}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ADRM1 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Although initially described as a cell membrane
CC       glycoprotein, ADRM1 is intracellular and non-glycosylated, and has
CC       probably no direct role in cell adhesion. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Zhou H., Di Palma S., Preisinger C., Peng M., Polat A.N., Heck A.J.,
RA   Mohammed S.;
RT   "Toward a comprehensive characterization of a human cancer cell
RT   phosphoproteome.";
RL   J. Proteome Res. 12:260-271(2013).
RN   [17]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT TYR-278, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=24275569; DOI=10.1016/j.jprot.2013.11.014;
RA   Bian Y., Song C., Cheng K., Dong M., Wang F., Huang J., Sun D.,
RA   Wang L., Ye M., Zou H.;
RT   "An enzyme assisted RP-RPLC approach for in-depth analysis of human
RT   liver phosphoproteome.";
RL   J. Proteomics 96:253-262(2014).
RN   [18]
RP   VARIANT [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] LEU-358, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS
RP   SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=21269460; DOI=10.1186/1752-0509-5-17;
RA   Burkard T.R., Planyavsky M., Kaupe I., Breitwieser F.P.,
RA   Buerckstuemmer T., Bennett K.L., Superti-Furga G., Colinge J.;
RT   "Initial characterization of the human central proteome.";
RL   BMC Syst. Biol. 5:17-17(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a ubiquitin E3 ligase and as an ISG15 E3
CC       ligase. Involved in innate immune defense against viruses by
CC       mediating ubiquitination of DDX58. Mediates 'Lys-63'-linked
CC       polyubiquitination of the DDX58 N-terminal CARD-like region which
CC       is crucial for triggering the cytosolic signal transduction that
CC       leads to the production of interferons in response to viral
CC       infection. Promotes ISGylation of 14-3-3 sigma (SFN), an adapter
CC       protein implicated in the regulation of a large spectrum signaling
CC       pathway. Mediates estrogen action in various target organs.
CC       Mediates the ubiquitination and subsequent proteasomal degradation
CC       of ZFHX3 (PubMed:22452784). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16352599,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17069755, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392790,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22452784}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-ubiquitinyl-[E2 ubiquitin-conjugating
CC       enzyme]-L-cysteine + [acceptor protein]-L-lysine = [E2 ubiquitin-
CC       conjugating enzyme]-L-cysteine + N(6)-ubiquitinyl-[acceptor
CC       protein]-L-lysine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392790}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + [ISG15] + [protein]-lysine = AMP +
CC       diphosphate + [protein]-N-ISGyllysine.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16352599}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts (via SPRY domain) with DDX58 (via CARD domain).
CC       Interacts (via coiled coil) with influenza A virus NS1 protein;
CC       this interaction specifically inhibits TRIM25 multimerization and
CC       TRIM25-mediated DDX58 CARD ubiquitination, thereby suppressing
CC       DDX58 signal transduction. Interacts with ZFHX3.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392790, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19454348,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22452784}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       F1BA49:- (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-2341129, EBI-9687469;
CC       O95786:DDX58; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2341129, EBI-995350;
CC       P03496:NS (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2341129, EBI-2547442;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392790}.
CC       Note=Colocalized with DDX58 at cytoplasmic perinuclear bodies.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in breast tumors (at protein level).
CC       Ubiquitous. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15130519,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22452784}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By interferons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16352599,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17069755}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RING-type zinc finger is important for ISG15 E3 ligase
CC       activity and autoISGylation. AutoISGylation negatively regulates
CC       ISG15 E3 ligase activity.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal B30.2/SPRY domain interacts with the first
CC       N-terminal CARD domain of DDX58.
CC   -!- PTM: Auto-ISGylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17222803}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Wikipedia; Note=TRIM25 entry;
CC       URL="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TRIM25";

RX   PubMed=24705253; DOI=10.1038/ng.2948;
RG   FORGE Canada Consortium;
RA   Mirzaa G.M., Parry D.A., Fry A.E., Giamanco K.A., Schwartzentruber J.,
RA   Vanstone M., Logan C.V., Roberts N., Johnson C.A., Singh S.,
RA   Kholmanskikh S.S., Adams C., Hodge R.D., Hevner R.F., Bonthron D.T.,
RA   Braun K.P., Faivre L., Riviere J.B., St-Onge J., Gripp K.W.,
RA   Mancini G.M., Pang K., Sweeney E., van Esch H., Verbeek N.,
RA   Wieczorek D., Steinraths M., Majewski J., Boycott K.M., Pilz D.T.,
RA   Ross M.E., Dobyns W.B., Sheridan E.G.;
RT   "De novo CCND2 mutations leading to stabilization of cyclin D2 cause
RT   megalencephaly-polymicrogyria-polydactyly-hydrocephalus syndrome.";
RL   Nat. Genet. 46:510-515(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Regulatory component of the cyclin D2-CDK4 (DC) complex
CC       that phosphorylates and inhibits members of the retinoblastoma
CC       (RB) protein family including RB1 and regulates the cell-cycle
CC       during G(1)/S transition. Phosphorylation of RB1 allows
CC       dissociation of the transcription factor E2F from the RB/E2F
CC       complex and the subsequent transcription of E2F target genes which
CC       are responsible for the progression through the G(1) phase.
CC       Hypophosphorylates RB1 in early G(1) phase. Cyclin D-CDK4
CC       complexes are major integrators of various mitogenenic and
CC       antimitogenic signals. Also substrate for SMAD3, phosphorylating
CC       SMAD3 in a cell-cycle-dependent manner and repressing its
CC       transcriptional activity. Component of the ternary complex, cyclin
CC       D2/CDK4/CDKN1B, required for nuclear translocation and activity of
CC       the cyclin D-CDK4 complex (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with either CDK4 or CDK6 protein kinase to form
CC       a serine/threonine kinase holoenzyme complex. The cyclin subunit
CC       imparts substrate specificity to the complex. Component of the
CC       ternary complex cyclin D/CDK4/CDKN1B required for nuclear
CC       translocation and modulation of CDK4-mediated kinase activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18827403}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P11802:CDK4; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-748789, EBI-295644;
CC       Q00535:CDK5; NbExp=13; IntAct=EBI-748789, EBI-1041567;
CC       P38936:CDKN1A; NbExp=14; IntAct=EBI-748789, EBI-375077;
CC       P46527:CDKN1B; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-748789, EBI-519280;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18827403}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18827403}. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18827403}. Note=Cyclin D-CDK4 complexes
CC       accumulate at the nuclear membrane and are then translocated into
CC       the nucleus through interaction with KIP/CIP family members.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 2: Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17873913}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P30279-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=Truncated;
CC         IsoId=P30279-2; Sequence=VSP_057295, VSP_057296;
CC         Note=Acts as proto-oncogene. Retains ability to bind CDK4, but
CC         unable to catalyze efficiently RB phosphorylation and
CC         inactivation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17873913};
CC   -!- PTM: Polyubiquitinated by the SCF(FBXL2) complex, leading to
CC       proteasomal degradation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22323446}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Megalencephaly-polymicrogyria-polydactyly-hydrocephalus
CC       syndrome 3 (MPPH3) [MIM:615938]: A syndrome characterized by
CC       megalencephaly, ventriculomegaly that may lead to hydrocephalus,
CC       and polymicrogyria; polydactyly may also be seen. There is
CC       considerable phenotypic similarity between this disorder and the
CC       megalencephaly-capillary malformation syndrome.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24705253}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclin family. Cyclin D subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=NIEHS-SNPs;
CC       URL="http://egp.gs.washington.edu/data/ccnd2/";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Central component of the TOM (translocase of outer
CC       membrane) receptor complex responsible for the recognition and
CC       translocation of cytosolically synthesized mitochondrial
CC       preproteins. Together with TOM22 functions as the transit peptide
CC       receptor at the surface of the mitochondrion outer membrane and
CC       facilitates the movement of preproteins into the TOM40
CC       translocation pore.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms part of the preprotein translocase complex of the
CC       outer mitochondrial membrane (TOM complex) which consists of at
CC       least 7 different proteins (TOM5, TOM6, TOM7, TOM20, TOM22, TOM40
CC       and TOM70). In the complex, interacts with TOM22.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10519552, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9774667}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P49334:TOM22; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-12522, EBI-12527;
CC       P23644:TOM40; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-12522, EBI-12539;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion outer membrane {ECO:0000305};
CC       Single-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5680 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Tom20 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR, AND TRANSMEMBRANE DOMAIN.
RX   PubMed=15001703; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0400512101;
RA   Zubkov S., Lennarz W.J., Mohanty S.;
RT   "Structural basis for the function of a minimembrane protein subunit
RT   of yeast oligosaccharyltransferase.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:3821-3826(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential subunit of the N-oligosaccharyl transferase
CC       (OST) complex which catalyzes the transfer of a high mannose
CC       oligosaccharide from a lipid-linked oligosaccharide donor to an
CC       asparagine residue within an Asn-X-Ser/Thr consensus motif in
CC       nascent polypeptide chains. N-glycosylation occurs
CC       cotranslationally and the complex associates with the Sec61
CC       complex at the channel-forming translocon complex that mediates
CC       protein translocation across the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). All
CC       subunits are required for a maximal enzyme activity. OST4 is
CC       required for recruitment of OST3 or OST6 to the OST complex. It is
CC       essential for cell growth at 37 but not at 25 degrees Celsius.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Dolichyl diphosphooligosaccharide + [protein]-
CC       L-asparagine = dolichyl diphosphate + a glycoprotein with the
CC       oligosaccharide chain attached by N-beta-D-glycosyl linkage to a
CC       protein L-asparagine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the oligosaccharyltransferase (OST) complex,
CC       which appears to exist in two assemblies comprising OST1, OST2,
CC       OST4, OST5, STT3, SWP1, WPB1, and either OST3 or OST6. OST3, OST4
CC       and STT3 probably form a subcomplex. May interact directly with
CC       OST2, OST3, OST5, OST6, STT3, WBP1 and SWP1. Interacts with SEC61,
CC       SBH1 and SSS1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10677492,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15831493, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15886282,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8175708, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9405463}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P48439:OST3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-12680;
CC       P52870:SBH1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-16410;
CC       P32915:SEC61; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-16400;
CC       P35179:SSS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-16406;
CC       P39007:STT3; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-18447;
CC       Q02795:SWP1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-12666;
CC       P33767:WBP1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-12658;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Single-pass
CC       type III membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2430 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the OST4 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [15]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.50 ANGSTROMS) OF 35-143 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   GLUTATHIONE, DISULFIDE BOND, MUTAGENESIS OF SER-123, FUNCTION, AND
RP   BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=20417731; DOI=10.1016/j.bbapap.2010.04.010;
RA   Li W.F., Yu J., Ma X.X., Teng Y.B., Luo M., Tang Y.J., Zhou C.Z.;
RT   "Structural basis for the different activities of yeast Grx1 and
RT   Grx2.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1804:1542-1547(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the glutathione system which performs
CC       several activities such as glutathione-dependent oxidoreductase,
CC       glutathione peroxidase and glutathione S-transferase (GST)
CC       activity. The disulfide bond functions as an electron carrier in
CC       the glutathione-dependent synthesis of deoxyribonucleotides by the
CC       enzyme ribonucleotide reductase. In addition, it is also involved
CC       in reducing cytosolic protein- and non-protein-disulfides in a
CC       coupled system with glutathione reductase. Required for resistance
CC       to reactive oxygen species (ROS) by directly reducing
CC       hydroperoxides and for the detoxification of ROS-mediated damage.
CC       GRX2 is more active as an oxidoreductase than GRX1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11875065, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684511,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18992757, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20417731,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9571241}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=2.0 mM for H(2)O(2) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11875065,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684511};
CC         KM=2.2 mM for tert-butyl hydroperoxide
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11875065, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684511};
CC         KM=0.87 mM for cumene hydroperoxide
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11875065, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684511};
CC         KM=0.17 mM for 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11875065, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684511};
CC         KM=0.27 mM for 1,2-dichloro-4-nitrobenzene
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11875065, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684511};
CC         KM=0.9 mM for reduced glutathione {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18992757};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11958675}.
CC       Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11958675}. Note=Two forms, a
CC       long and a short one are found in the mitochondrion, but only the
CC       short one is detected in the cytoplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: In response to exposure to reactive oxygen species
CC       (ROS) and upon entry into stationary phase.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10786615, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9571241}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 31400 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: It is unclear whether the long polypeptide observed
CC       in mitochondria represents the immature form of the protein before
CC       cleavage of the transit peptide and release of the short form into
CC       the cytoplasm or whether two mature isoforms exists.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutaredoxin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAB23389.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RA   Yatime L., Hein K.L., Nilsson J., Nissen P.;
RT   "Structure of the RACK1 dimer from Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 411:486-498(2011).
RN   [18]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.00 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22096102; DOI=10.1126/science.1212642;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Garreau de Loubresse N., Melnikov S., Jenner L.,
RA   Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;
RT   "The structure of the eukaryotic ribosome at 3.0 A resolution.";
RL   Science 334:1524-1529(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel
CC       (PubMed:22096102). Located at the head of the 40S ribosomal
CC       subunit in the vicinity of the mRNA exit channel, RACK1 serves as
CC       a scaffold protein that can recruit other proteins to the
CC       ribosome. Involved in the negative regulation of translation of a
CC       specific subset of proteins (PubMed:15340087).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15340087, ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the small ribosomal subunit (SSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). RACK1 is
CC       located at the head of the SSU in the vicinity of the mRNA exit
CC       channel (PubMed:15340087, PubMed:15334071, PubMed:22096102). RACK1
CC       interacts with the mRNA-binding protein SCP16 (PubMed:15012629).
CC       RACK1 also exists simultaneously as a homodimer in a cytosolic
CC       non-ribosome-bound form (PubMed:21704636).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15012629, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15334071,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15340087, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21704636,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 333112 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WD repeat G protein beta family.
CC       Ribosomal protein RACK1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA89753.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [31]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.04 ANGSTROMS) OF 90-180, X-RAY
RP   CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.82 ANGSTROMS) OF 380-589, RNA-BINDING, RRM DOMAINS,
RP   AND MUTAGENESIS OF HIS-105; VAL-132; LEU-141; ASN-172; SER-174;
RP   HIS-504 AND PHE-506.
RX   PubMed=23782695; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M113.463901;
RA   Zhang W., Zeng F., Liu Y., Zhao Y., Lv H., Niu L., Teng M., Li X.;
RT   "Crystal structures and RNA-binding properties of the RNA recognition
RT   motifs of heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein L: insights into its
RT   roles in alternative splicing regulation.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 288:22636-22649(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Splicing factor binding to exonic or intronic sites and
CC       acting as either an activator or repressor of exon inclusion.
CC       Exhibits a binding preference for CA-rich elements
CC       (PubMed:11809897, PubMed:22570490, PubMed:24164894,
CC       PubMed:25623890, PubMed:26051023). Component of the heterogeneous
CC       nuclear ribonucleoprotein (hnRNP) complexes and associated with
CC       most nascent transcripts (PubMed:2687284). Associates, together
CC       with APEX1, to the negative calcium responsive element (nCaRE) B2
CC       of the APEX2 promoter (PubMed:11809897).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11809897, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22570490,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25623890, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26051023,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2687284}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Identified in a IGF2BP1-dependent mRNP granule complex
CC       containing untranslated mRNAs (PubMed:17289661). Interacts with
CC       HNRNPLL (PubMed:18669861). Interacts with APEX1; the interaction
CC       is DNA-dependent (PubMed:11809897). Component of a complex with
CC       SETD2 (PubMed:19332550). Interacts with ELAVL1 (PubMed:18161049).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11809897, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17289661,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18161049, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18669861,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19332550}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P22626:HNRNPA2B1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16071645, EBI-299649;
CC       Q12906:ILF3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16071645, EBI-78756;
CC       P40337:VHL; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-719024, EBI-301246;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17289661, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2687284,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:26051023}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17289661}. Note=Localized in cytoplasmic mRNP
CC       granules containing untranslated mRNAs. These granules are not
CC       identical with P bodies or stress granules.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17289661}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P14866-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P14866-2; Sequence=VSP_044301;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: RRM domain 2 has moderate RNA-binding affinity. RRM
CC       domains 3 and 4 may facilitate RNA looping when binding to two
CC       appropriately separated binding sites within the same target pre-
CC       mRNA (PubMed:23782695). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23782695}.
CC   -!- PTM: Several isoelectric forms of the L protein are probably the
CC       results of post-translational modifications.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-544 by CaMK4 enhances interaction with
CC       a CaMK4-responsive RNA element (CaRRE1), and prevents inclusion of
CC       the stress axis-regulated exon (STREX) of the KCNMA1 potassium
CC       channel transcripts upon membrane depolarization.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22570490}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Excess hnRNP L activates NMD of its own mRNA by
CC       promoting the inclusion of a 'poison exon' containing a premature
CC       stop codon and leading to nonsense-mediated decay. It also cross-
CC       regulates inclusion of an analogous 'poison exon' in the hnRNP L-
CC       like pre-mRNA (PubMed:19124611). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:19124611}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA34261.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
